description: Harvest festival celebrated in Tamil Nadu to thank the Sun God for agricultural abundance. Features special rice dish preparation, cattle decoration, and community gatherings.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Rigorous traditional training system requiring years of discipline, starting from childhood with eye exercises, body conditioning, and expression practice.
Magnificent Dravidian temple architecture in Madurai featuring gopurams (towering gateways), mandapas (pillared halls), and thousands of stone sculptures depicting mythological scenes.
Tribal art form from Maharashtra using simple geometric shapes and stick figures on mud walls to depict daily life, celebrations, and connection with nature.
World's largest religious gathering occurring every 12 years at four riverside locations where millions gather to bathe in sacred waters for spiritual purification.
South Indian classical music system emphasizing vocal performance with melodic improvisation within structured compositions, accompanied by violin, mridangam, and tambura.
Four-day festival dedicated to Sun God and Chhathi Maiya (Mother Goddess), involving fasting, standing in water, and offering prayers at sunrise and sunset.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Traditional health practice of adjusting diet, lifestyle, and daily routines according to changing seasons (Ritucharya) to maintain balance and prevent illness.
source: Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India

description: Ancient folk art from Bihar region featuring colorful geometric patterns, mythological figures, and nature motifs, traditionally created by women on freshly plastered mud walls.
Nine-night festival honoring the feminine divine, celebrated through fasting, prayer, dance (Garba/Dandiya), and regional customs across India.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Sacred thread ceremony marking a boy's transition to formal education and spiritual life, involving mantras, rituals, and symbolic rebirth into the student phase.
Ritual dance worship from Kerala where performers embody deities through elaborate costumes, face painting, and intense physical movements to bless communities.
Harvest festival marking the Sikh New Year, commemorating the formation of the Khalsa by Guru Gobind Singh, celebrated with processions, fairs, and bhangra dancing.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Ancient system of mathematical calculations based on 16 sutras (formulas) from the Vedas, enabling mental arithmetic and simplified problem-solving techniques.
Traditional tie-dye textile art from Gujarat and Rajasthan creating intricate patterns by tying small portions of fabric before dyeing, symbolizing joy and fertility.
Traditional sequence of 12 yoga postures performed as a salutation to the sun, combining physical exercise, breath control, and meditation.
source: Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India

description: Traditional village council governance structure resolving disputes, managing resources, and making community decisions, now formalized in modern governance.
source: National Council of Educational Research and Training

description: Classical dance form from Andhra Pradesh originally performed as dance-drama by male troupes, characterized by graceful movements, speech, and rhythmic footwork.
Sixteen traditional adornments for Indian brides including bindi, sindoor, alta, bangles, and anklets, each with symbolic significance for marital auspiciousness.
Ancient lost-wax metal casting technique creating tribal figurines and functional items with distinctive primitive patterns and motifs.
Festival celebrating Lord Krishna's birth with fasting, devotional singing, baby Krishna worship, and dahi handi (breaking of curd pot) competitions.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Temple consecration ceremony performed every 12 years to recharge the divine energy of the temple and its deities through elaborate rituals and mantras.
Classical dance from Manipur blending devotional themes with delicate, graceful movements and circular patterns inspired by Krishna and Radha's love.
Five-fold Ayurvedic detoxification therapy including oil massage, steam therapy, and cleansing procedures to remove toxins and restore bodily balance.
source: Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India

description: Double ikat silk textile from Gujarat requiring intricate pre-dyeing of both warp and weft threads before weaving to create precise geometric patterns.
Festival honoring Lord Ganesha with elaborate public installations, home worship, and immersion processions, especially celebrated in Maharashtra.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Ancient Sanskrit theater tradition from Kerala recognized by UNESCO as Intangible Cultural Heritage, featuring elaborate eye movements and hand gestures.
Intricate paper cutting art form from Mathura region creating delicate stencil designs of Krishna stories and nature motifs for ritual and decorative purposes.
Women's festival celebrating the monsoon season and Goddess Parvati's union with Lord Shiva, featuring fasting, swinging, and wearing green bangles and clothing.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Ritual floor art from Kerala using natural colored powders to create divine images of deities like Kali and Ayyappan for temple worship.
Classical dance form from Odisha characterized by tribhangi (three-part body bends), mudras (hand gestures), and fluid torso movements depicting divine stories.
UNESCO World Heritage site featuring 7th-8th century temples blending northern Nagara and southern Dravidian architectural styles with intricate stone carvings.
Classical dance tradition from Assam originating in Vaishnava monasteries (sattras), featuring graceful movements depicting Krishna's life and teachings.
Delicate white-on-white embroidery technique from Lucknow using shadow-work and fine stitches to create floral patterns on cotton and muslin fabrics.
Ancient festival of Karnataka honoring Draupadi as divine mother, featuring a male priest carrying a floral pyramid on his head in procession.
Tribal art form using distinctive patterns of dots and lines to create vibrant depictions of nature, folklore, and daily life with natural pigments.
Assamese festival marking agricultural cycles with three distinct celebrations throughout the year, featuring traditional dance, feasting, and community gatherings.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Martial dance form from eastern India combining elements of combat techniques with expressive storytelling, often performed with distinctive masks.
Exquisite marble temples at Dilwara featuring some of the world's finest marble carvings with intricate ceiling panels, pillars, and doorways.
Daily ritual of creating geometric patterns with rice flour at thresholds to welcome prosperity, positive energy, and provide food for insects and small creatures.
Traditional theater form from Karnataka combining dance, music, dialogue, costume, and makeup to depict mythological stories with vibrant characters.
Traditional five-metal alloy crafting technique for temple idols combining gold, silver, copper, iron, and zinc/lead to create sacred sculptures.
Women's festival celebrating marital fidelity and honoring Goddess Gauri, featuring processions, fasting, and decorative displays of the goddess.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Structured martial arts education system progressing through body control, wooden weapons, metal weapons, and finally weaponless combat techniques.
Classical South Indian painting style using gold leaf, glass beads, and precious stones to create ornate devotional images with raised surfaces.
Ritual marriage ceremony between the sacred Tulsi plant and Lord Vishnu, marking the beginning of the wedding season after the monsoon.
Mystical minstrel tradition from Bengal combining elements of Vaishnavism and Sufism through wandering singers who spread spiritual messages through songs.
Ritual art of Rathwa and Bhilala tribes creating wall paintings depicting their creation myth and invoking deities for healing and prosperity.
New Year festival in Andhra Pradesh, Telangana and Karnataka marking the beginning of the Hindu lunar calendar with special dishes combining six flavors.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Devotional folk dance from Karnataka dedicated to Lord Mahadeshwara, featuring rhythmic movements while playing cymbal-like instruments.
Traditional temple orchestra from Kerala using five instruments in a rhythmic ensemble that builds in tempo and complexity throughout the performance.
Ancient textile art using natural dyes and hand-carved blocks to create mythological narratives and floral patterns on cotton fabric.
Snake worship festival where milk offerings are made to snake deities and images, celebrating the ecological and mythological significance of serpents.
Classical dance form from Kerala known as the 'dance of the enchantress,' characterized by graceful, swaying movements and white and gold costumes.
Traditional craft of creating fine cashmere shawls from the undercoat of Himalayan mountain goats, featuring intricate embroidery and patterns.
Harvest festival marking the sun's transition into Capricorn, celebrated with kite flying, sesame sweets, and ritual bathing in sacred rivers.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Daily routine practices prescribed in Ayurveda including morning hygiene, oil pulling, self-massage, and specific eating patterns to maintain health.
source: Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India

description: Metal handicraft technique from Bidar using an alloy of zinc and copper inlaid with thin sheets of silver to create distinctive black and silver items.
Kerala New Year festival featuring the Vishukkani arrangement of auspicious items viewed first thing in the morning, along with gift-giving and feasting.
Traditional dance form from Odisha performed by young boys dressed as girls, precursor to Odissi, featuring acrobatic movements and backbends.
Ritual dance performed during Durga Puja holding terracotta incense burners, creating smoke while performing rhythmic movements to honor the goddess.
Intricate temple hangings depicting Lord Krishna's life, created on cloth with detailed brushwork, gold embellishments, and vibrant natural colors.
Parsi New Year celebration featuring house cleaning, new clothes, decorative tables with symbolic items, and community feasting to mark spring's arrival.
Manipuri martial art combining spear (thang) and sword (ta) fighting techniques with ritual dance elements, showcasing precision and agility.
Ritual floor and wall art from Kumaon region using rice paste on red background to create geometric and symbolic designs for auspicious occasions.
Buddhist festival in Ladakh commemorating Guru Padmasambhava's birth with masked dances (Cham) performed by monks, music, and monastery celebrations.
Ancient storytelling art form from Tamil Nadu using a bow-shaped musical instrument (villu) for percussion while narrating mythological stories through songs.
Rare craft technique using castor oil-based paint applied with metal styluses to create intricate designs on fabric without touching the surface.
Ancient classical vocal music form emphasizing precision in note rendering, systematic development, and spiritual expression with minimal ornamentation.
Tribal wall painting tradition from Jharkhand created by women during harvest festival using natural pigments to depict animals and nature motifs.
Women's ritual of tying threads around banyan trees while fasting and praying for their husbands' longevity, based on the legend of Savitri and Satyavan.
Satirical dance-drama form created by poet Kunchan Nambiar as social commentary, featuring solo performer in colorful costume with rhythmic movements.
Winter folk festival celebrating the harvest and winter solstice with bonfire, singing, dancing, and offering sesame seeds, jaggery, and popcorn to fire.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Ritual theater performance from Kerala dedicated to Goddess Kali, featuring elaborate face painting, costumes, and choreographed combat sequences.
Traditional cloth-based scroll painting from Odisha featuring intricate mythological narratives, using natural colors and detailed ornamentation.
Sixteen-day period dedicated to honoring ancestors through food offerings, prayers, and rituals performed at sacred rivers or temples.
Powerful women's dance form from Maharashtra combining sensual movements with folk songs addressing social issues, romance, and seasonal themes.
Scroll painting tradition from Rajasthan depicting heroic folk tales and legends on long cloth scrolls used by traveling bards during performances.
Three-day festival in Odisha celebrating Mother Earth's menstruation, during which agricultural work stops and women enjoy swings and special foods.
Ancient Sanskrit theater tradition from Kerala recognized by UNESCO as Intangible Cultural Heritage, featuring elaborate eye movements and hand gestures.
Festival observed by married women who fast from sunrise to moonrise for the wellbeing and longevity of their husbands, breaking fast only after sighting the moon through a sieve.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Traditional debut performance of a Bharatanatyam dancer after completing years of training, marking the transition from student to performer with a full-length solo recital.
Ancient rock-cut Buddhist cave monuments dating from the 2nd century BCE, featuring elaborate paintings and sculptures depicting Buddhist teachings and Jataka tales.
Traditional embroidery technique from Punjab using bright colored threads to create geometric patterns and floral designs on shawls and garments for special occasions.
Kashmiri Pandit New Year celebration featuring ritual viewing of a thali containing rice, yogurt, salt, and other auspicious items first thing in the morning.
Elaborate facial makeup process for Kathakali performers using natural pigments and rice paste to create character-specific designs that can take 3-4 hours to apply.
Festival celebrating the bond between brothers and sisters, where sisters apply tilak on brothers' foreheads, pray for their wellbeing, and exchange gifts.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Structured martial arts education system progressing through body control, wooden weapons, metal weapons, and finally weaponless combat techniques.
Mystical minstrel tradition from Bengal combining elements of Vaishnavism and Sufism through wandering singers who spread spiritual messages through songs.
Intricate geometric patterns drawn with rice flour at home entrances during Pongal festival, featuring symbols of sun and harvest prosperity.
Energetic folk dance from Assam performed during Bihu festival, characterized by rapid hip movements, hand gestures, and colorful traditional attire.
Classical dance form from Kerala known as the 'dance of the enchantress,' characterized by graceful, swaying movements and white and gold costumes.
Traditional display of dolls and figurines arranged on odd-numbered steps during Navaratri, depicting mythology, culture, and everyday life scenes.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Traditional Rajasthani folk dance performed by women in flowing ghagra skirts moving in circular formations, originally associated with the Bhil tribe.
Energetic harvest dance from Punjab performed to the rhythm of the dhol drum, featuring high jumps, shoulder shakes, and colorful attire.
Nationalist tradition of worshipping India personified as a mother goddess, featuring temples dedicated to Bharat Mata with relief maps of undivided India.
Traditional dance form of the Kalbelia snake-charmer community from Rajasthan, featuring swirling black skirts mimicking serpent movements.
Sanskrit theater tradition from Kerala recognized by UNESCO as Intangible Cultural Heritage, featuring elaborate eye movements and hand gestures.
Festival celebrating the birth of Lord Rama, the seventh incarnation of Lord Vishnu, featuring fasting, prayers, recitation of the Ramayana, and processions with idols of Rama, Sita, and Hanuman.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Harvest festival marking the Sikh New Year and formation of the Khalsa, celebrated with processions, bhangra dancing, and community meals, while also considered auspicious for new beginnings by Hindus.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Festival honoring Lord Ganesha's birth with installation of clay idols in homes and public spaces, prayers, devotional music, offerings of sweets, and culminating in idol immersion ceremonies.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Ten-day festival celebrating Lord Rama's victory over demon king Ravana, featuring Ramlila performances, processions, and culminating in the burning of large effigies of Ravana, Meghnath, and Kumbhakarna.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Night festival dedicated to Lord Shiva, observed with all-night vigils, fasting, temple worship, abhishekam (ritual bathing of the lingam), and offerings of bel leaves and milk.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Festival marking the arrival of spring and honoring Goddess Saraswati, the deity of knowledge and arts. People wear yellow clothes, prepare yellow dishes, and students place books and instruments before the goddess for blessing.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Ancient oral tradition of reciting Vedic texts using precise pronunciation, pitch, duration, and specific hand gestures to preserve the integrity of sacred knowledge across generations.
Traditional performance art depicting episodes from the Ramayana epic, performed annually during Dussehra with elaborate costumes, dialogues, and music, often spanning several days.
Ancient spiritual discipline combining physical postures, breath control, meditation, and ethical principles to achieve harmony between mind, body, and spirit, codified in Patanjali's Yoga Sutras.
source: Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India

description: Traditional practices for temple visits including ritual bathing beforehand, removing footwear, circumambulating the shrine clockwise, and making offerings of flowers, fruits, and coconuts to deities.
Periodic abstinence from specific foods or all food for spiritual purification, expressing devotion, and seeking divine blessings, practiced during festivals, specific weekdays, or personal vows.
Traditional greeting performed by joining palms in front of the chest with a slight bow, acknowledging the divine in others and showing respect without physical contact.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Tibetan Buddhist painting tradition adopted in Himalayan regions of India, featuring detailed depictions of deities, mandalas, and spiritual events on cotton or silk using natural pigments and gold leaf.
Classical dance form originating from Tamil Nadu, characterized by bent knees, precise footwork, expressive eyes, and hand gestures (mudras) that tell stories from Hindu mythology.
Classical dance form from North India featuring intricate footwork, pirouettes, and graceful movements that blend Hindu and Islamic influences.
Classical dance-drama from Kerala characterized by elaborate costumes, face paintings, and stylized gestures to portray characters from Hindu epics.
Iconic marble mausoleum in Agra built by Emperor Shah Jahan for his wife Mumtaz Mahal, representing the pinnacle of Mughal architecture and a symbol of eternal love.
Agricultural festival honoring bulls and oxen for their role in farming, featuring bull decoration, processions, and special treats for the animals.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Traditional bamboo dance from Mizoram where dancers move between rhythmically clapped bamboo poles, requiring precise timing and coordination.
Distinctive white-on-white embroidery created by the Toda tribe of Nilgiri Hills, featuring geometric patterns with red and black accents on shawls.
Annual cultural showcase celebrating the heritage of Nagaland's 16 tribes through traditional performances, crafts, sports, and food.
Traditional running stitch embroidery from Bengal using old saris to create quilts, wall hangings, and garments with narrative and decorative motifs.
Women's ritual in Kerala where millions of women prepare sweet rice porridge in earthen pots as offering to the Bhagavathy temple deity.
Traditional Sikh martial art form using wooden sticks to simulate swords, practiced as self-defense and during religious processions.
Narrative painting tradition from Bengal where artists create scrolls depicting mythological stories and social themes, singing as they unfurl them.
Tibetan New Year celebration observed in Himalayan regions with prayer ceremonies, masked dances, and community feasting.
Traditional metal craft from Assam creating utensils and decorative items using an alloy of copper and tin, known for distinctive sound quality.
Kerala's traditional culinary practice emphasizing balanced flavors, medicinal properties, and seasonal ingredients in vegetarian and non-vegetarian dishes.
Martial dance form from eastern India combining elements of combat techniques with expressive storytelling, often performed with distinctive masks.
Traditional Gujarati fermented food preparation technique using rice and chickpea flour, creating spongy, savory cakes with tempering.
source: Ministry of Tourism, Government of India

description: Traditional folk songs of the nomadic Kalbelia tribe of Rajasthan, recognized by UNESCO as Intangible Cultural Heritage.
Traditional handloom technique from Manipur creating women's sarongs with distinctive borders and patterns, governed by strict cultural protocols.
Traditional hand-block printing technique using natural dyes and wooden blocks to create geometric and floral patterns on textiles.
Ancient coastal temple dedicated to Goddess Parvati as the virgin deity, featuring Dravidian architecture and maritime cultural significance.
Martial folk dance from Gujarat depicting scenes of battle and victory using swords and sticks, performed during festivals and celebrations.
Traditional metal casting technique using five sacred metals (gold, silver, copper, iron, and zinc) to create temple deities according to ancient texts.
Classical devotional compositions by poet Jayadeva describing Krishna and Radha's love, performed in Odissi dance and classical music.
Tiger dance performed during Onam festival in Kerala where performers paint their bodies as tigers and hunters, enacting playful hunting scenes.
Traditional healing system of the Kani tribe using forest herbs and plants, with specialized knowledge passed down through generations.
source: Ministry of AYUSH, Government of India

description: Evening ritual worship of River Ganges at Varanasi, Haridwar, and Rishikesh featuring synchronized rituals with lamps, flowers, and chanting.
Traditional ear ornament from Kerala featuring large disc-shaped gold earrings that stretch the earlobe, symbolizing cultural identity.
Traditional folk theater form from Gujarat featuring balancing acts, storytelling, and social commentary, often performed on raised platforms.
Tribal harvest festival celebrated after Diwali in Jharkhand, featuring cattle worship, wall paintings, and community dancing.
Traditional handwoven shawls from Nagaland with tribe-specific patterns and motifs that denote social status, achievements, and tribal identity.
Ancient writing system of the Lepcha tribe of Sikkim, one of the oldest scripts in the Himalayan region, used to document folk tales and traditions.
Elaborate floor designs created by women in Andhra Pradesh during Sankranti festival using rice flour, featuring geometric patterns and nature motifs.
Traditional technique of the Konyak Naga tribe to create fire by friction using bamboo and wood, preserved as cultural heritage.
Folk dance from Punjab and Haryana performed by women during Teeyan festival, featuring circular formations and graceful movements.
Distinctive marriage tradition of the Kodava community featuring unique rituals like bride wearing ancestral sword and ceremonial exchange of betel leaves.
Traditional communal houses in Nagaland serving as dormitories for young men, centers for tribal education, and repositories of cultural knowledge.
Biennial festival of the Silk Weaver community in Odisha honoring their patron goddess with processions, rituals, and cultural performances.
Traditional mural art technique from Konkan region using red oxide on wet lime plaster to create religious imagery in temples and homes.
World's largest open-air theatrical performance held annually in Bargarh, Odisha, enacting Krishna's life with the entire town as stage.
Traditional slash-and-burn agricultural practice in Northeast India, involving community cooperation and sustainable forest management.
Percussion ensemble from Kerala featuring chenda drums in temple festivals, with complex rhythmic patterns and synchronized performance.
Vibrant mirror and thread embroidery tradition of the nomadic Lambani tribe, featuring bold colors, coins, and shells on traditional garments.
Harvest festival of Assam featuring community feasting, bonfires, traditional sports, and the building of temporary huts called meji and bhelaghar.
Traditional craft using tall grass to create mats, baskets, and utility items, particularly practiced in rural Bengal and Assam.
Ceremonial procession during Gangaur festival in Rajasthan where women carry decorated images of Goddess Gauri on their heads to water bodies.
Distinctive weaving tradition of the Mishmi tribe of Arunachal Pradesh, creating geometric patterns with natural fibers and dyes.
Folk dance from Tamil Nadu where performers balance decorated pots on their heads while dancing to rhythmic music, often as temple offerings.
Week-long ritual of the Rathwa tribe where wall paintings are created to honor their deity Baba Pithoro, accompanied by music and trance dances.
Sacred chants of the Toda tribe of Nilgiri Hills, featuring distinctive vocal techniques and language, performed during rituals and ceremonies.
Traditional water harvesting and conservation techniques of the nomadic Kalbelia tribe, adapted to desert environments of Rajasthan.
Tibetan Buddhist painting tradition adopted in Himalayan regions of India, featuring detailed depictions of deities, mandalas, and spiritual events on cotton or silk.
Unique aspect of Kuchipudi dance where performers dance on the edges of a brass plate while balancing a pot of water on the head.
Shamanic healing ceremony of Bhil and Rathwa tribes involving the creation of sacred paintings to invoke deities for curing illness.
Traditional dance from Meghalaya where performers move between rhythmically clapped bamboo poles, requiring precise timing and coordination.
Traditional textile art creating narrative temple cloths depicting mythological scenes using natural dyes and hand-carved blocks.
Elaborate decoration of bulls and oxen during Pola festival in Maharashtra, featuring ornamental headgear, embroidered cloths, and painted horns.
Traditional facial and body tattooing practice of the Konyak Naga tribe, once marking accomplished warriors and tribal identity.
Traditional hereditary record keepers of Karnataka who maintained genealogical records of communities across generations using palm leaf manuscripts.
Ritual dance of the Khond tribe of Odisha performed during agricultural festivals, featuring distinctive rhythmic movements and traditional instruments.
Traditional storytelling art form using portable wooden shrines with painted panels that unfold to reveal religious narratives as the storyteller recites.
Tribal practice of using sacred paintings for divination and forecasting, performed by specialized priests among the Rathwa and Bhilala tribes.
Fine handloom weaving technique creating lightweight fabric with square patterns (khat) using cotton and silk threads, originating in Rajasthan.
Traditional performance art where artists unfurl painted scrolls while singing stories of deities and epics, traveling between villages.
Community-protected sacred groves in Meghalaya maintained through traditional ecological knowledge and religious beliefs, preserving biodiversity.
Traditional technique of creating natural dyes from plants, minerals, and insects for Kalamkari textile art, using mordants to fix colors.
Ritual decoration of cattle during Pongal festival in Tamil Nadu, featuring painted horns, flower garlands, and bells to honor their agricultural contribution.
Traditional bamboo crafting techniques of the Kuki tribe creating utilitarian and decorative items using only hand tools and indigenous knowledge.
Performance tradition where artists display narrative scroll paintings while singing stories of mythology and folk tales to village audiences.
Traditional gambling practice in Meghalaya based on archery results, deeply embedded in cultural life and community gatherings.
Folk art style originating near Kolkata's Kalighat temple, depicting religious themes, social commentary, and daily life with bold outlines and vibrant colors.
Traditional organic farming system in Kerala alternating rice cultivation and prawn farming in brackish water, creating a sustainable ecosystem.
Ritual paintings of the Kurumba tribe from Nilgiri Hills using natural pigments to create sacred images for ceremonies and healing practices.
Annual cultural festival held against the backdrop of UNESCO World Heritage Pattadakal temples, showcasing classical dance forms of India.
Traditional harvest ceremony of the Khond tribe (modified from historical practice) honoring Earth Goddess with offerings and community celebrations.
Intricate geometric embroidery tradition from Karnataka using running stitches to create complex patterns on garments, particularly on Ilkal saris.
Elaborate tiger face and body painting technique for Pulikali performers during Onam festival, using natural and synthetic colors with specialized application methods.
Distinctive marriage traditions of the agricultural Kurmi community featuring symbolic plowing ceremony, grain offerings, and community feasting.
Scroll painting tradition from West Bengal where artists create narrative paintings on paper scrolls and sing the stories as they unfurl them.
Community contests held during Pongal festival to create the most intricate and beautiful rice flour designs at thresholds, judged on complexity and precision.
Distinctive needlework tradition from Kutch region featuring mirror work, vibrant colors, and intricate patterns specific to different communities.
Ritual snake worship songs performed by the Pulluvan community in Kerala, using distinctive string instruments and rhythmic patterns to invoke snake deities.
Rare celebration occurring once every 12 years when the Kurinji flower blooms across the Western Ghats, marked by tribal gatherings and rituals.
Traditional silk sari weaving technique from Karnataka featuring distinctive red borders and geometric patterns, worn during auspicious ceremonies.
Ceremonial procession of caparisoned elephants during temple festivals in Kerala, featuring gold-plated accoutrements and parasols.
Pastoral knowledge system of the Kuruba community including animal husbandry techniques, weather prediction, and seasonal migration patterns.
Distinctive painting style from Himalayan regions featuring delicate brushwork, vibrant colors, and themes of Rajput court life and Krishna legends.
Village goddess worship festival in Andhra Pradesh featuring animal sacrifice (now often symbolic), spirit possession, and community feasting.
Traditional cotton check weaving technique of the Kunbi tribal community of Goa, featuring distinctive red and white patterns.
Ancient port city excavation in Kerala revealing Indo-Roman trade connections, with artifacts showing cultural exchange dating back 2000 years.
Traditional bamboo crafting techniques of the nomadic Kuravan-Kurathi community, creating baskets, mats, and utilitarian items while traveling.
Traditional board game played on a cross-shaped board with cowrie shells or dice, featuring strategic movement of pieces around the board.
source: National Council of Educational Research and Training

description: Distinctive tradition of Ramayana performance in Uttarakhand, featuring unique musical compositions, costumes, and continuous performance over several days.
Traditional food practices of the fishing communities of Kerala, featuring distinctive seafood preparations, preservation techniques, and cooking methods.
Harvest festival of the Garo tribe celebrating the sun god Saljong, featuring drumming, colorful costumes, and synchronized dance movements.
Ten-day festival in Karnataka celebrating the victory of good over evil, featuring the Mysore Palace illumination, procession of decorated elephants, and cultural performances.
Monsoon festival of the Jaintia tribe in Meghalaya to ward off plague and disease, featuring colorful wooden structures, drumming, and ritual cleansing.
Buddhist festival in Sikkim commemorating Buddha's birth, enlightenment, and death, featuring prayer flags, processions, and charitable activities.
Contemporary cultural gathering in Arunachal Pradesh showcasing indigenous music alongside modern genres, held in the traditional Apatani tribal village setting.
Floral festival celebrated by women in Telangana, creating elaborate flower stacks that are worshipped and then immersed in water bodies.
Biennial tribal festival in Telangana honoring tribal goddesses, drawing millions of devotees for offerings and rituals in the forest region.
Flag festival of Goa celebrating the resolution of land disputes between villages, featuring colorful flags, mock fights with soft weapons, and music.
Month-long celebration in Madurai commemorating the celestial wedding of Goddess Meenakshi and Lord Sundareswarar, featuring elaborate processions and rituals.
Annual fertility festival at Kamakhya Temple in Assam marking the annual menstruation course of the goddess, with the temple remaining closed for three days.
Tribal festival of the Gond people worshipping the serpent deity, featuring distinctive rituals, tribal dances, and a ceremony where women offer their first-born's hair.
Traditional festival of the Apatani tribe in Arunachal Pradesh celebrating friendship, fertility, and prosperity through sacrificial offerings and community rituals.
Cultural celebration held against the backdrop of UNESCO World Heritage ruins, featuring classical dance, music, puppet shows, and rural sports.
Post-sowing celebration of the Ao Naga tribe featuring traditional singing, dancing, feasting on rice beer, and community bonding activities.
Cultural showcase in Ladakh featuring masked dances, traditional music, archery competitions, and polo matches against the backdrop of Buddhist monasteries.
source: Ministry of Tourism, Government of India

description: Floral festival in Mizoram celebrating the cultivation of anthuriums, featuring flower exhibitions, cultural performances, and agricultural knowledge sharing.
Annual tourism festival in Manipur named after the state's endangered brow-antlered deer, showcasing indigenous sports, crafts, cuisine, and performing arts.
Three-day monastic festival in Arunachal Pradesh featuring masked lama dances to drive away evil spirits and bring prosperity to the community.
Manipuri New Year celebration featuring house cleaning, preparing special meals, and climbing nearby hills in the belief that it elevates humans to greater heights in life.
Spring festival of the Konyak Naga tribe marking the beginning of the agricultural cycle, featuring traditional dances, songs, and feasting.
Seven-day royal ritual in Tripura worshipping the fourteen gods of the royal Tripuri people, featuring animal sacrifices and elaborate ceremonies.
Spring festival of the Tripuri people honoring Lord Garia for good harvest and prosperity, featuring bamboo pole decorations and community dancing.
Sikkimese New Year marking the end of the harvest season, featuring masked dances, archery competitions, and traditional food and drink.
Winter festival along the banks of Aie River in Assam promoting tourism through river activities, indigenous games, food, and cultural performances.
Unique Sikkimese festival paying homage to Mount Khangchendzonga as the guardian deity, featuring warrior dances and offerings.
Annual fair in Shantiniketan, West Bengal, celebrating the founding of the Brahmo Samaj with folk performances, handicrafts, and rural traditions.
Traditional dance drama from Manipur depicting the divine love between Krishna and the gopis, performed with classical movements and devotional music.
Manipuri martial art combining spear and sword techniques with ritualistic elements, developed for warfare and now preserved as cultural heritage.
Masked snow lion dance from Sikkim performed during Buddhist festivals, symbolizing the strength and fearlessness of the Himalayan people.
Traditional dance form of the Reang tribe in Tripura performed by young women balancing on earthen pitchers while moving their lower bodies with precise control.
Traditional greeting of the Nyishi tribe in Arunachal Pradesh involving specific hand gestures and verbal exchanges based on age and social status.
Bamboo dance from Mizoram where dancers move between rhythmically clapped bamboo poles, requiring precise timing and coordination.
Energetic drum dance from Manipur performed during Holi celebrations, featuring acrobatic movements while playing the dhol (drum).
Five-day royal festival dance of the Khasi tribe honoring the goddess Ka Blei Synshar for good harvest and prosperity of the kingdom.
Traditional narrative songs of the Zeliang tribe in Nagaland preserving oral history, cultural values, and community knowledge through generations.
Ritual dance component of Manipur's Lai Haroba festival depicting the creation of the universe and human beings through stylized movements.
Thanksgiving dance festival of the Khasi tribe in Meghalaya celebrating spring and good harvest, with men and women performing in traditional attire.
Ancient lost-wax metal casting technique creating tribal figurines and functional items with distinctive primitive patterns and motifs.
Traditional handloom technique of the indigenous Lepcha tribe of Sikkim creating distinctive patterns and motifs on cotton and woolen fabrics.
Distinctive black pottery from Manipur made by mixing serpentine stone with clay, hand-shaped without a wheel, and smoke-fired to create durable cookware.
Traditional handmade paper craft of the Monpa tribe in Arunachal Pradesh using the bark of the Shugu Sheng tree through a multi-step process.
Intricate craft technique from Bihar using golden-yellow sikki grass to create ritual objects, jewelry, and decorative items through coiling and binding.
Specialized craftsmanship from Northeast India creating furniture, household items, and decorative objects using indigenous techniques of splitting, weaving, and binding.
Intricate bead embellishment tradition of Naga tribes creating symbolic patterns on shawls, headgear, and ceremonial attire denoting tribal identity and status.
Traditional leather puppet making from Andhra Pradesh, involving elaborate processes of treating, cutting, painting, and perforating leather to create translucent puppets.
Specialized bamboo weaving techniques of the Khasi tribe creating utilitarian and ritual baskets with distinctive patterns and functional designs.
Traditional facial tattooing practice of Apatani women featuring distinctive nose plugs and facial lines, originally developed as a protective measure.
Intricate mirror and thread work tradition of the nomadic Rabari community, featuring bold geometric patterns and symbolic motifs on textiles and garments.
Distinctive tribal art form using dots and dashes to create vibrant depictions of daily life, mythology, and nature, originally created on hut walls.
Traditional ornaments of the Konyak Naga tribe featuring brass heads, animal teeth, and hornbill feathers, historically worn by successful warriors.
Traditional dance form of the Dimasa tribe in Assam performed with bamboo poles, featuring intricate footwork and rhythmic movements.
Traditional ceremony of the Angami Naga tribe involving the communal pulling of a large monolith to commemorate significant events or deceased community leaders.
Annual harvest festival of the Nyishi tribe in Arunachal Pradesh invoking the earth goddess Nyokum for good harvest and community wellbeing.
Traditional dormitory system for young men in Mizoram serving as educational institution for tribal customs, warfare techniques, and community service.
Traditional social structure of the Khasi tribe where lineage, inheritance, and family name pass through the female line, with the youngest daughter as custodian of family property.
Manipuri New Year celebration featuring house cleaning, preparing special meals, and climbing nearby hills in the belief that it elevates humans to greater heights in life.

Elaborate funeral ritual of the Karbi tribe lasting several days, featuring buffalo sacrifices, feasting, and dance to guide the deceased's soul to the afterlife.
Harvest festival of the Reang tribe in Tripura celebrating the end of the agricultural cycle with community dancing, feasting, and traditional sports.
Sustainable agricultural system of the Apatani tribe combining rice cultivation with fish farming in the same fields without using chemical fertilizers.
Traditional celebration of the winter solstice by the Bhutia community in Sikkim featuring masked dances, prayer ceremonies, and community feasting.

Sustainable agricultural technique developed by the Angami Naga tribe creating elaborate terraced fields on hillsides for rice cultivation.

Religious festival of the Dimasa tribe in Assam honoring their ancestral deities with animal sacrifices, ritual dances, and community feasting.
Traditional technique of the Khiamniungan Naga tribe to create fire using bamboo, dried grass, and friction methods, preserved as cultural heritage.

Traditional guest welcoming dance of the Mizo people performed during festivals and special occasions to honor visitors with rhythmic bamboo movements.
Traditional poetic expressions of the Khasi tribe using metaphors, proverbs, and rhythmic patterns to convey moral lessons and community wisdom.
Traditional head gear of the Nyishi tribe in Arunachal Pradesh made from hornbill beak and feathers, now replaced with sustainable alternatives to protect the bird.
Religious festival of the Ao Naga tribe honoring their supreme deity Lijaba with prayers for good harvest, health, and community prosperity.
Traditional narrative musical form of Manipur using the pena (single-stringed fiddle) to accompany stories, myths, and historical accounts.
Sacred ritual of the Khasi tribe involving animal sacrifice to honor ancestral deities and seek blessings for the community's welfare.
Major festival of the Apatani tribe celebrating friendship, fertility, and prosperity through sacrificial offerings and community rituals.
Traditional drum-based music of the Mizo people using bamboo and wooden drums in various sizes to create complex rhythmic patterns for ceremonies and dances.

Maharashtrian New Year celebration marked by raising a gudi (bamboo stick with silk cloth, neem leaves, and marigold flowers) outside homes, preparing special foods, and performing rituals for prosperity.
source: Ministry of Culture, Government of India

description: Annual chariot festival where massive wooden chariots carrying Lord Jagannath, Lord Balabhadra, and Goddess Subhadra are pulled through the streets by thousands of devotees.
Cultural celebration held against the backdrop of the majestic Kumbhalgarh Fort, featuring folk performances, traditional music, and crafts exhibition.

Annual livestock fair and cultural festival featuring camel trading, competitions, folk performances, and religious rituals at the sacred Pushkar Lake.
Assamese spring festival marking the agricultural new year, featuring community dancing, feasting, and traditional games and sports.
Festival dedicated to Sun God Surya, featuring ritual bathing at sunrise and prayers for health and prosperity, especially celebrated in South India.

Women's festival in Kerala where millions of women prepare sweet rice porridge as offering to the Attukal Bhagavathy temple deity, recognized as the largest gathering of women for a religious activity.
Tamil festival honoring Lord Murugan, featuring devotees carrying kavadis (physical burdens) and performing acts of devotion through body piercing and endurance.
Traditional livestock fair and cultural festival featuring bull trading, camel races, cockfights, and folk performances.

Bengali folk theater tradition performed in open-air stages, featuring melodramatic acting, singing, and dancing to depict mythological and historical stories.

Storytelling tradition from Andhra Pradesh where performers narrate tales using song, dance, and dialogue while playing instruments like tambura and tala.

Traditional religious discourse combining storytelling, music, and philosophy, especially popular in Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh.
Devotional Sufi music tradition featuring rhythmic singing, hand clapping, and harmonium accompaniment to express divine love.

Traditional tribal dance from western Odisha performed by young women during harvest season, featuring graceful movements and romantic themes.

Tribal dance from Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, and Odisha performed around the Karma tree during the Karma festival for good harvest.

Spring festival of Mizoram celebrated after clearing jungle areas for jhum cultivation, featuring bamboo dance performances, traditional games, and community feasting.

Intricate mirror and thread work tradition of the nomadic Rabari community, featuring bold geometric patterns and symbolic motifs on textiles and garments. Characterized by chain stitch, mirror work (shisha), and vibrant colors that reflect their desert heritage and mythology through motifs like peacocks, camels, elephants, and the tree of life.
